statement.tex: \text{What is the minimum value (if it exists) of }\\ \quad y = \dfrac{x}{\ln x^2} \\ \textbf{Note: }\ln = \log_e

step.context: \text{Given }y=\dfrac{x}{\ln x^2},\text{ can we say the following}\\ \text{by looking at }\dfrac{dy}{dx}?
\text{Going further, is the following true at the}\\ \text{extrema point }x = e?
step.tex: \text{There is a minima at } x = e.\\ \textbf{And the minimum value is } y = \dfrac{e}{2}.
\text{There is a maxima - not minima - at } x = e.\\ \textbf{And the maximum value is } y = \dfrac{e}{2}.
step.reason: \begin{align} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{1}{2}\cdot \left[\dfrac{1}{\ln x}-\dfrac{1}{(\ln x)^2}\right]\\ \implies\dfrac{d^2 y}{dx^2} &= \dfrac{1}{2}\cdot \left[-\dfrac{1}{x\cdot (\ln x)^2} + \dfrac{2}{x\cdot (\ln x)^3}\right] \\ &= \dfrac{1}{2x\cdot (\ln x)^2}\cdot \left(\dfrac{2}{\ln x} - 1 \right) \\ \implies \left[\dfrac{d^2 y}{dx^2}\right]_{x=e} &= \dfrac{1}{2e\cdot (\ln e)^2}\cdot \left(\dfrac{2}{\ln e} - 1\right) \\ &= \dfrac{1}{2e}\gt 0\implies\text{ minima.} \\ \text{And so, }y_{MIN} &= \left[\dfrac{x}{\ln x^2}\right]_{x=e} = \dfrac{e}{2\ln e} = \dfrac{e}{2}. \end{align}
